p: A novel alternative approach used for larvicidal activity, besides MeNPs, is represented by nanoemulsions, which in this case can be obtained using essential oil from Artemisia spp., knowing that the essential oil components have larvicidal activity. It has been demonstrated that the essential oil isolated from A. vulgaris has larvicidal and repellent action against Aedes aegypti through its major components (α-humulene, β-caryophyllene, and caryophyllene oxide) [ 206]. However, essential oils also have disadvantages such as high volatility [ 221, 222], low water solubility [ 222, 223], and lack of stability in the presence of air, heat, and light, followed by oxidation [ 223].
